episodeTitle: The Crewmates' Whereabouts - The Giant Gravestone and Panties of Gratitude
description: Zoro and Perona stumble upon a massive gravestone on Kuraigana Island, encountering weapon-wielding Humandrills. Meanwhile, Brook decides to remain on Namakura Island to repay his debt to the people of Harahettania before reuniting with his crew.

events.title: Perona Returns Zoro's Swords
events.description: Perona, frustrated with Zoro's inability to navigate the castle and find his hidden swords due to his poor sense of direction, finally gives up and returns his swords to him directly. This is an anime-original scene not shown in the manga.
events.significance: Establishes Perona and Zoro's dynamic on Kuraigana Island and highlights Zoro's notorious directional challenges.

events.title: Zoro and Perona Head to the Sea
events.description: Zoro and Perona begin their journey toward the sea, with Zoro intending to return to Sabaody Archipelago to reunite with his crew. They traverse through the foggy, ruined landscape of Kuraigana Island.
events.significance: Shows Zoro's determination to reunite with the Straw Hat crew despite being separated.

events.title: Discovery of the Giant Gravestone
events.description: Zoro and Perona stumble upon an enormous cross-shaped gravestone in what appears to be an ancient battlefield. The massive tombstone is a remnant of the Shikkearu Kingdom, which fell after a war nine years prior.
events.significance: Introduces a key landmark on Kuraigana Island and hints at the island's dark history, setting up Zoro's future encounter with Mihawk.

events.title: Humandrills Attack Zoro
events.description: Weapon-wielding baboons called Humandrills emerge from the forest and attack Zoro with swords. These intelligent primates learned combat techniques by observing the war that destroyed the Shikkearu Kingdom nine years ago.
events.significance: Introduces the Humandrills, formidable opponents that will later become part of Zoro's training regimen under Mihawk.

events.title: Flashback to the Straw Hats' Separation
events.description: The episode includes flashbacks showing how Bartholomew Kuma separated the Straw Hat crew at Sabaody Archipelago, with each member being sent to different locations across the world.
events.significance: Provides context for why the crew members are scattered and reminds viewers of the traumatic separation event.

events.title: Brook Learns of the Debt to Harahettania
events.description: On Namakura Island, Brook is informed by Pekkori and the cultists about their struggles with the Longarm Tribe and the debt of gratitude they owe him for his help in defeating them. The people wish to repay Brook's kindness.
events.significance: Establishes Brook's moral character and sets up his decision to delay reuniting with his crew to help those in need.

events.title: Brook Decides to Stay and Repay His Debt
events.description: Despite his desire to reunite with Luffy and the crew, Brook makes the honorable decision to remain on Namakura Island temporarily to help the people of Harahettania. However, the Longarm Tribe members have other plans and kidnap Brook.
events.significance: Shows Brook's growth as a character who values honor and gratitude, setting up his future as a famous musician with the Longarm Tribe as his managers.

events.title: Brook's Panty Request
events.description: Using his status as the supposed 'Satan' that the cultists summoned, Brook humorously requests to see women's underwear as part of his 'divine compensation', staying true to his perverted skeleton character.
events.significance: Provides comic relief and reinforces Brook's signature character trait while also explaining the episode's unusual title.

quotes.text: I must repay the debt I owe to these people before I can return to my crew.
quotes.speaker: Brook
quotes.context: Brook's decision to stay on Namakura Island

themes.description: Brook's decision to delay reuniting with his crew to repay a debt demonstrates the importance of honoring obligations and showing gratitude.
themes.symbolism: The 'Panties of Gratitude' in the title, while comedic, represents the people's desire to repay Brook for his help.
culturalReferences: Japanese concepts of on (debt/obligation) and giri (duty/honor)

themes.description: Despite being separated from his crew, Zoro remains determined to find his way back to Sabaody Archipelago and reunite with his nakama.
themes.symbolism: The giant gravestone represents the obstacles and challenges Zoro must overcome on his journey.

themes.description: Both Zoro and Brook must adapt to their new circumstances while maintaining their goal of reuniting with the crew.
themes.symbolism: The Humandrills learning combat techniques from observation parallels how the Straw Hats must learn and grow from their separation.

characterSpotlights.development: Zoro continues his journey to return to Sabaody, showcasing his poor directional sense but also his determination to reunite with his crew. His encounter with the Humandrills foreshadows future challenges.
keyActions: Receives his swords back from Perona
Travels toward the sea with Perona

characterSpotlights.development: Brook demonstrates his honorable nature by choosing to delay reuniting with his crew to repay a debt to the people who helped him, showing character growth beyond his comedic skeleton persona.
keyActions: Learns about the debt to Harahettania
Decides to stay and help the people
Gets kidnapped by the Longarm Tribe
quotes: I must repay the debt I owe to these people before I can return to my crew.

characterSpotlights.development: Perona shows a softer side by returning Zoro's swords and accompanying him, while still maintaining her tsundere personality.
keyActions: Returns Zoro's swords after getting frustrated with his poor navigation
Reacts to the discovery of the giant gravestone and Humandrills

mangaDifferences.difference: The anime added a scene showing Perona giving Zoro his swords back onscreen, which was not explicitly shown in the manga cover pages.
Extended scenes of the Namakura Island cultists and their interactions with Brook were expanded in the anime.
The episode is based on manga cover pages rather than main story chapters, meaning most content was anime-original expansion of brief cover story panels.

trivia.fact: This is the final episode of the Straw Hat's Separation Serial arc, which showed where each crew member ended up after being separated by Bartholomew Kuma.
The episode achieved a 12.7% viewership rating in Japan, ranking 2nd for that week.
The Humandrills that appear in this episode learned their combat skills by observing a war that destroyed the Shikkearu Kingdom nine years before the current story timeline.
The opening song 'Kaze wo Sagashite' is performed by Mari Yaguchi, a former member of the J-pop group Morning Musume, along with the Straw Hat voice actors.

sources.title: Kaze wo Sagashite - One Piece Wiki

trivia.fact: The Longarm Tribe members who kidnap Brook at the end of this episode later become his managers when he becomes the famous 'Soul King' during the two-year timeskip.
Namakura Island's name means 'lazy' or 'cowardly' in Japanese, referencing the inhabitants' initial passiveness before Brook's arrival.
